comments.body: We usually just omit the `-default` part if there is no default. That way you only need to check if `$certificateHash` is `$null` or not to determine whether it was set.

Thanks for checking it out. It looks like I did this because the binding object returned by get-webbinding puts empty strings in certhash/certstore rather than null so comparing to $null wasn't working. I can probably just do if ($string) instead and get rid of that default to make it cleaner.

I'll test it soon.
Cool, if you need it as empty that's fine I just wasn't sure if you set that on purpose.
Ok. If it's alright to leave it, I'd like to.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +16,20 @@$port = Get-AnsibleParam $params -name "port" -default '80'
$ip = Get-AnsibleParam $params -name "ip" -default '*'
$certificateHash = Get-AnsibleParam $params -name "certificate_hash" -type str -default ([string]::Empty)
$certificateStoreName = Get-AnsibleParam $params -name "certificate_store_name" -type str -default ([string]::Empty)
$sslFlags = Get-AnsibleParam $params -name "ssl_flags" -default '0' -ValidateSet '0','1','2','3'

comments.body: Is it guaranteed that BindingInformation always contains 2 `:` in that particular format?

Yah. Confirmed on all versions of Windows we support and per the docs:

https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.web.administration.binding.bindinginformation.aspx

If it ever changed though, 1 colon instead of 2, I don't think it would alter the behavior. What's behind the 2nd colon is the host_header value....so without it `$args[0].hostheader -eq $splits[2]` would fail which is the behavior we are looking for anyways in the event that a host header is not defined.
